Based on my own meager knowledge, I would agree with Gordon but the 
new So=
theby's catalog lists a tsuba that looks very Kyo to me as 
Heianjo. (lot n=
o 722) It then goes on to list a few pages of Kyo 
tsuba.  It would seem th=
at by their working definition that Curran's 
explanation of Ko-Kyo might b=
e correct given that the Heianjo is 
early-mid 15th C while the others are =
more than a century later.

obson <robsongo@s...> 
wrote:
> Hi,

> The old term Heianjo Sukashi is no=
 longer in use having been 
replaced

r book, you will still see this 
> term. This also helps avoid confusion wi=
th Heianjo tsuba, which 
are 
> typically thin iron plates with brass inlay=
s.

> Gordon
